title: 108_hr3146
content:
SEC. 101. Extension of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through March 31, 2004. Activities authorized by part A of title IV of the Social Security Act, and by sections 510, 1108(b), and 1925 of such Act, shall continue through March 31, 2004, in the manner authorized for fiscal year 2002. Grants and payments may be made for carrying out such activities during the first two quarters of fiscal year 2004 at the level provided for the first two quarters of fiscal year 2002. Grants and payments may be made for carrying out activities authorized by part A of title IV of the Social Security Act through March 31, 2004, at the level provided for the first two quarters of fiscal year 2002. Amendments are made to section 403(a)(3)(H) of the Social Security Act for supplemental grants in certain states. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act for supplemental grants in certain states, contingency fund, and maintenance of effort for fiscal year 2001 and 2004. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changes for fiscal years 2001, 2004, and 2005 regarding supplemental grants, contingency fund, and maintenance of effort. Extension of the national random sample study of child welfare and child welfare waiver authority is extended through March 31, 2004. Activities authorized by sections of the Social Security Act will continue with necessary appropriations. Grants and payments can be made for these activities during the first two quarters of fiscal year 2004 at the same level as in 2002. TITLE II--TAX PROVISIONS

SEC. 201. Amends section 6103(l)(13) of the Internal Revenue Code to extend disclosure of return information for student loan repayment until December 31, 2004.

SEC. 202. Adds a new section to extend Internal Revenue Service user fees. SEC. 202 extends Internal Revenue Service user fees under Chapter 77 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees for requests to the IRS for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters. Fees will vary by categories, based on the time and difficulty of complying with requests, and must be paid in advance. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees for requests to the IRS, varying by categories and payable in advance. Exemptions and reduced fees will be provided as determined appropriate. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees for requests to the IRS, varying by categories and payable in advance. Exemptions and reduced fees will be provided as determined appropriate, including an exemption for certain requests regarding pension plans. The Secretary will not require user fees for determination letters on pension plans maintained by eligible employers or trusts. The pension benefit plan must meet certain requirements by the end of the fifth plan year or within the first 5 plan years for any remedial amendment period. The text discusses the requirements for a pension benefit plan, including definitions of terms like eligible employer and pension benefit plan. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "plan" as a pension, profit-sharing, stock bonus, annuity, or employee stock ownership plan, and defines an "eligible employer" as one with at least 1 non-highly compensated employee participating in the plan. The determination of eligibility is based on the date of the request. The determination of whether an employer is an eligible employer under subparagraph (B) is based on the date of the request. Any request to which subparagraph (B) applies shall not be taken into account for the determination of average fees charged under the program required by subsection (a). The average fee charged under the program shall not be less than a certain amount. The average fee charged under the program required by subsection (a) shall not be less than a certain amount determined in a table. The fees for various rulings and determinations range from $200 to $350. The fees for exempt organization determination and chief counsel ruling range from $200 to $300. No fee will be imposed for requests made after December 31, 2004. The Revenue Act of 1987 and the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 are repealed. Fees collected under section 7528 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 must be approved by an appropriations Act before being spent by the IRS. These amendments apply to requests made after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there is an extension of COBRA fees under Title III - Trade Provisions. Title III of the Act extends COBRA fees from September 30, 2003, to March 31, 2004. The amendment extends the sunset provision of the Social Security Act to March 2004 for medicare cost-sharing. Additionally, the total amount available for allocation is adjusted by removing references to fiscal year 2002. The amendment extends the sunset provision of the Social Security Act to March 2004 for medicare cost-sharing and adjusts the total amount available for allocation by removing references to fiscal year 2002. The amendment extends the sunset provision of the Social Security Act to March 2004 for medicare cost-sharing and adjusts the total amount available for allocation by removing references to fiscal years 2002 and 2003. Additionally, a special rule is added for the first quarter of 2004 regarding the selection and assistance of qualifying individuals. The Social Security Act is amended to include a special rule for the period from January 1, 2004, to March 31, 2004. During this time, a State must select qualifying individuals and provide them with assistance, with a total allocation amount of $100,000,000. SEC. 402. Extension of provision equalizing urban and rural standardized Medicare inpatient hospital payments. The amendment in the Miscellaneous Appropriations Act, 2003 changes the deadline from September 30, 2003, to March 31, 2004. The effective date of the amendments is subject to the Secretary of Health and Human Services' determination of administrative feasibility. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may delay the implementation of amendments until November 1, 2003 if it is not administratively feasible. The Secretary may delay implementing amendments until November 1, 2003 to comply with Congressional intent. If delayed, adjustments will be made for fiscal year 2004 payments. If the Secretary delays implementing amendments until November 1, 2003, adjustments will be made for fiscal year 2004 payments to ensure total payments for inpatient hospital services remain the same. If the Secretary delays implementing amendments until November 1, 2003, adjustments will be made for fiscal year 2004 payments to ensure total payments for inpatient hospital services remain the same. The application of the amendments will not affect payment rates or amounts for services after September 30, 2004. The application of subparagraphs (A) and (B) will not impact payment rates or amounts for services after September 30, 2004. The Secretary can implement these provisions through program memoranda without the need for rulemaking or notice in the Federal Register. The Secretary has the authority to implement provisions without rulemaking or notice in the Federal Register, and there is no review of delays or determinations under this paragraph. The Secretary has the authority to implement provisions without rulemaking or notice in the Federal Register, and there is no review of delays or determinations under this paragraph. Additionally, there shall be no administrative or judicial review of any delay or determination made by the Secretary under this paragraph or the application of the payment rates determined. The curr_chunk can be summarized as: 
"Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States."
